newsitem.title: NICARAGUA: Nicaragua tense as election results challenged.
newsitem.headline: Nicaragua tense as election results challenged.

text.p: Brooding tension reigned on Managua's streets on Tuesday, as Sandinista ex-revolutionaries muttered oaths about a disputed presidential election and ordinary citizens feared street violence.
"At the grass roots level, party activists are angry, angry, angry," said Antonia Tiffer, a Sandinista militant.
Tempers were nearly at breaking point among Sandinistas in some rural northern regions, she added, especially former war zones where revolutionaries fought U.S. backed-Contra rebels in the 1980s.
The army spoke of a "tense but calm" situation across the country, saying that people were unhappy but had so far contained their anger.

But in the northern province of Matagalpa, opposition politicians alleged that observers had found 3,000 Sandinista ballots concealed in a house. They also said Sandinista supporters had seized and beaten up a man who had allegedly stolen 1,000 more Sandinista votes and hidden them in his car.
The report could not be confirmed.

Partial official results on Tuesday showed Sandinista candidate Daniel Ortega had failed to regain the presidency that he occupied from 1979-1990, losing by a margin of nearly 10 points to portly right-wing lawyer Arnoldo Aleman.
But Ortega claimed "serious irregularities" and "fraudulent intentions" had marred Sunday's vote and refused to accept defeat.

At the headquarters of the left-wing Sandinista Front, in run-down old taxis and in talk on the capital's rutted and dilapidated streets, nervous citizens wondered if the Sandinista's powerful grassroots would rise up against the official results.
Some Sandinistas said they were ready to lash out at what many viewed as election fraud but party bosses held them back.

Ortega's campaign manager Alvaro Fiallos was on a damage control mission on Tuesday, calling party officials, radio stations and television channels in a bid to pass on the message: "Remain calm, and don't do anything rash".

"I'm half angry, half sad," said Sandinista activist David Flores outside a sombre party headquarters. "It was a shameless fraud. We wanted to rise up against it, but the party leadership asked us to remain calm."
Top Sandinista officials on Tuesday said their leader had a legal right to challenge the vote count, and denied that he was stirring up trouble after an embarrassing loss.
In a country torn apart in the 1980s by pro- and anti- Sandinista armies, memories of how quickly the country could degenerate into left-right warfare were fresh.
Rivalry between Aleman and Ortega was intense. During the campaign both men slammed each other as quasi-dictators bent on driving Nicaragua back to its oppressive past.
Aleman said he hoped "Comandante Ortega has matured" and called on the Sandinistas to accept the voters' verdict.
The pain of defeat was bolstered by the jubilant, and at times mocking, celebrations of Aleman's supporters, who let off fireworks throughout the night and partied wildly.
Sitting in front of a giant revolutionary portrait in the Sandinista Worker's Centre headquarters, activist Alex Reyes Cuaresma promised a show of strength if fraud was proven.

"If the elections were not clean, there's going to be a massive peaceful reaction by the Sandinista Front to show that we still have power, we still have bases, and we are capable of defending ourselves," he said.
